awd_titl_txt: A Youth-Led Citizen Science Network for Community Environmental Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing a technology-rich, out-of-school time STEM program for underserved middle and high school youth. The new program features citizen science activities involving mobile sensors, drones, mapping software, and other technologies associated with environmental science data collection and careers. Four learning modules will be developed that focus on air, noise, and soil pollution, and how factors associated with land use contribute to different types of pollution. Field data will be compared to land cover classifications to examine how pollutants are related to and influenced by natural and built environments. Participants will also use their developing technology skills to communicate their findings to larger audiences using a website, digital stories, videos, and citizen science cafes. In the science cafes, youth will gain leadership skills by guiding their parents or caregivers, siblings, and the community at large in citizen science activities. This project extends the typical pattern of citizen science projects by having participants go beyond joining established citizen science projects to initiating their own projects grounded in issues and affordances of their local communities. If successful, the model from this project has the potential to be broadly adapted to other communities and linked to research of local or regional interest or importance.

This design and development project will directly engage 45 students in grades 8 and 9, with potential for reaching over 300 individuals as participants' families and community members become involved in citizen science cafes. Most project activities will take place at government subsidized housing sites. The program progresses through five elements: curriculum development, instructor preparation, immersive summer sessions, school-year sessions for participating youth, and citizen science cafes. The project will develop four teaching modules: Air Pollution, Noise Pollution, Soil Pollution, and Natural and Built Environments. Students will gain experience with field research methods while learning to collect high-quality data using various sensors and related technologies. They will use the data to answer scientific questions. A mixed methods approach will be employed to examine outcomes related to the research questions: (1) How does participation in community-focuses environmental citizen science impact the development of three aspects of science: performance, competence, and recognition as a scientist?(2) To what extent and how does participation in community-focused environmental citizen science activities move youth towards full participation in the science community? and (3) How do levels of performance, competence, and recognition influence progress towards full participation in the science community? Data sources will include a student science identity survey, a test of relevant knowledge, a student interview protocol, a student observation protocol, student artifact rubrics, and a parent/caregiver interview protocol. Interviews will be conducted with student participants at regular intervals, and with parents/caregivers at the end of program sessions. 
 
This project will expand the existing ITEST portfolio by addressing important questions relating to community-relevant curricula, linkages of formal and informal education, and examining potential new elements of STEM learning ecosystems, including the use of student-initiated citizen science endeavors and youth-led citizen science cafes. Through the embedded research, this project will also advance understanding of science identity development and its relationship to STEM occupational choices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In order to pursue a STEM career path, students must be able to visualize themselves working in that career. However, many students, especially those in underrepresented groups, don't identify with STEM or with being a scientist. Citizen science [now more often called participatory sciences] involves the participation of the general public in scientific research and has the potential to offer meaningful and relevant STEM experiences for youth. These types of authentic science experiences may help youth to develop and strengthen their science identity as they engage in science tasks and interact with scientists. The Y-CITYSCI: A Youth-Led Citizen Science Network for Community Environmental Assessment project developed, implemented, and studied an out-of-school time STEM program in which underserved middle and high school youth participated in and designed technology-rich community-focused citizen science projects. The project team hypothesized that by engaging in the program experiences, students would be better able to see themselves as future scientists.

From the fall of 2019 through the summer of 2022, the project team implemented an out of school time program centered on environmental exposure assessment--the characterization of human exposure to surrounding media (air, soil, water, etc.). Students met after school during the fall and spring semesters (meetings were held over Zoom during the pandemic) to learn about environmental science topics, types of environmental pollution, ways to use technology such as air monitors and drones to collect environmental data, and how they could participate in  scientific work as citizen scientists. The program also included two summer research academies where students had the opportunity to work with university faculty to design and carry out a research project that was relevant and interesting to them. Each research academy culminated in a conference-style poster presentation session with family and community members in attendance. Over 100 high school students participated in the program.

 

The project team also conducted research into youth science identity development using surveys, interviews, short questionnaires, and observations of program activities. Researchers interviewed 29 youth participants who had attended the summer research academies, asking questions about their experiences in the program, their other science experiences and perceptions, their likes and dislikes regarding science, and their career interests and plans. Findings from these interviews indicate that a person's pre-existing image or definition of a scientist has an impact on whether or not they feel they could be a scientist. Other aspects that may strengthen or weaken youth science identity are interest in science, self-efficacy in science, recognition as a scientist by self and others, and one's community or context. Also, the interview results indicated that the youth distinguished between being a "science person" and being a scientist.

Research findings, as well as informal feedback from the youth participants and project team members, informed the creation of a set of guidelines for hosting youth-led science cafés. Guidelines include fostering student agency, scaffolding career awareness, supporting the guest scientist, and closing the event with intentionality.

This project also produced a curriculum based on the after-school and summer program. Using research findings and feedback from students, teachers, and team members, nine-units (40 activities) focused on environmental pollution assessment were developed. Activities focus on using technology to gather and analyze data, providing students with authentic science experiences. When possible, citizen science apps are used as one method of data collection and data sharing. Activity plans include embedded links to resources (including relevant apps) and other support materials needed by instructors (e.g., worksheets, answer keys, web-based simulations). The curriculum is available free for download at https://ycitysci.wordpress.com/2023/07/07/our-full-curriculum-is-now-live-and-freely-available-for-download/
